application.name: photcorri
application.brief: Apply Lommel-Seeliger, ROLO, Minnaert, and McEwen photometric corrections to multiband cubes

description.p: photcorri implements photometric correction using four photometric models (Lommel-Seeliger, ROLO, Minnaert, and McEwen) adopted by the OSIRIS-REx project, based on the paper of "Takir et al. (2015): Photometric Models of Disk-integrated Observations of the OSIRIS-REx target Asteroid (101955) Bennu, Icarus, 252, 393-399." 141, 205-225 (1999). Takir et al. (2015) defined the following equations for I/F photometric correction:
description.PRE: I/F = M_PI * ALS * F(alpha) * [mu0 / (mu + mu)] where: mu0 = cos(incidence) mu = cos(emission) F(phase) = exp(BETA * phase + GAMMA * phase^2 + DELTA * phase^3
I/F = F(alpha) * [mu0 / (mu + mu)] where: mu0 = cos(incidence) mu = cos(emission) F(phase) = C0*exp(-C1*phase) + A0 + A1*phase + A2*phase^2 + A3*phase^3 + A4*phase^4
I/F = M_PI * AM * (mu0)^kalpha * m^(kalpha-1) * F(phase) where: mu0 = cos(incidence) mu = cos(emission) kalpha = K0 + B * alpha F(phase) = 10^-(Beta * ALPHA + GAMMA * alpha^2 + Theta * alpha^3)

I/F = M_PI * AMC * ( (2 * Lalpha * mu0 / mu0 + mu) + (1 - Lalpha) * mu0) where: mu0 = cos(incidence) mu = cos(emission) kalpha = K0 + B * alpha Lalpha = exp(BETA * alpha + GAMMA * alpha^2 + DELTA * alpha^3
description.p: The equations described above utilize the Lommel-Seeliger, Rolo, Minnaert, and Mcewen functions to account for scattering dependance on incidence and emission angles.

This application provides features that allow multiband cubes to be photometrically corrected with a properly formatted PVL input file much like that of ISIS program photomet. This application restricts much of the options available to the more sophiscated photomet application.

The Incref, Emaref and Pharef are the incidence, emission and phase angles to be used as the photometric standard. It will be used to normalize the photometric correction parameter to these angles. The equation used to create the photometrically corrected I/F is:
description.PRE: I/F_corr(Inc_o, Em_o, Pha_o) = I/F_model(Inc_o, Em_o, Pha_o) * [ I/F_measure(IncMeasure, EmMeasure, PhaMeasure) / I/F_model(IncMeasure, EmMeasure, PhaMeasure) ] where (incMeasure, EmMeasure, PhaMeasure) is the scaterring geometry of measured reflectance. The most commonly used reference geometries for correction are (Inc_o, Emc_o, Pha_o) = (0, 0, 0), which corresponds to the normal reflectance, and (inc_o, Emc_o, Pha_o) = (30, 0, 30), which is a common laboratory setting.
description.p: An additional feature of the PVL structure is that any keyword that exists in the Object section of the PhotometricModel Object is propagated to each Algorithm group when it is read in unless the keyword already exists in the Algorithm group. If a keyword exists in both the PhotometricModel object and an Algorithm group, the keyword in the Algorithm group has precedence.

Below is an example of a small PVL file that will process all bands that have a center wavelength of 100.0 to 900.0 (units do not matter as long as the PVL ALgorithm groups contain the same units as the BandBin Center keyword in the input cube file). The units of phase is provided in Radians for this particular example and is overridden from the keyword in the PhotometricModel object:
description.PRE: Object = NormalizationModel Group = Algorithm Name = Albedo PhotoModel = Lommel-Seeliger, Rolo, Minnaert, or McEwen Incref=30.0 Emaref=0.0 Pharef=30.0 EndGroup EndObject
description.p: Additional consequences of the photometric correction processing is any incidence angle greater than 90 degrees is set to the ISIS special Null pixel value. And, of course, any ISIS special pixel encountered on input is propagated to the output TO file without modification.

history.change: Used functor with ProcessCube to remove global variables.

parameter.name: FROM
parameter.description: Use this parameter to select the input filename.

parameter.name: TO
parameter.description: This file will contain the photometrically corrected image data after being corrected with Lommel-Seeliger, Rolo, Minnaert, or McEwen algorithms.

parameter.name: PHOTMODEL
parameter.brief: Pvl file contains the four model parameters used for the photometric correction: Rolo, Lommel-Seeliger, Minnaert, and McEwen
parameter.description: This file contains the four model parameters used for the photometric correction. See the main program documentation for a full description.

parameter.name: MAXINCIDENCE
parameter.brief: Maximum incidence angle to trim image
parameter.description: The maximum number of degrees allowed for the incidence angle in order to retain the data. This number must be between 0.0 and 90.0.

parameter.name: MAXEMISSION
parameter.brief: Maximum emisson angle to trim image
parameter.description: The maximum number of degrees allowed for the emission angle in order to retain the data. This number must be between 0.0 and 90.0.

parameter.name: MAXPHASE
parameter.brief: Maximum phase angle to trim image
parameter.description: The maximum number of degrees allowed for the phase angle in order to retain the data. This number must be between 0.0 and 90.0.

parameter.name: INCIDENCE
parameter.brief: Maximum incidence angle to trim image
parameter.description: The maximum number of degrees allowed for the incidence angle in order to retain the data. This number must be between 0.0 and 90.0.

parameter.name: EMISSION
parameter.brief: Maximum emisson angle to trim image
parameter.description: The maximum number of degrees allowed for the emission angle in order to retain the data. This number must be between 0.0 and 90.0.

parameter.name: PHASE
parameter.brief: Maximum phase angle to trim image
parameter.description: The maximum number of degrees allowed for the phase angle in order to retain the data. This number must be between 0.0 and 90.0.

parameter.name: USEDEM
parameter.brief: Use DEM instead of ellipsoid for photometric angle calculations
parameter.description: Phase, Emission, and Incidence angles can be calculated from the elipsoid (default) or from the DEM. The difference is that using the DEM the surface roughness is taken into account.
